tn.text: John continues to describe the part of the vision about the seven angels with the seven plagues. The seven plagues are the seven bowls of God's wrath.
The word "I" refers to John.

The image of the wine in the bowls can be stated clearly. The word "wrath" here refers to punishment. The wine is a symbol for punishment. AT: "bowls full of the wine that represents God's wrath." See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:15:07|15:7]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]])
The word "bowl" refers to what is in it. AT: "poured out the wine from his bowl" or "poured out God's wrath from his bowl" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"painful wounds." These could be infections from diseases or injuries that have not healed.
This was an identifying mark that indicated that the person who received it worshiped the beast. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:13:15|13:17]].

The word "bowl" refers to what is in it. AT: "poured out the wine from his bowl" or "poured out God's wrath from his bowl." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:16:02|16:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to all the salt water lakes and oceans. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

The word "bowl" refers to what is in it. AT: "poured out the wine from his bowl" or "poured out God's wrath from his bowl." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:16:02|16:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: rivers and the springs of water
tn.text: This refers to all bodies of fresh water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Possible meanings are 1) this refers to the third angel who was in charge of pouring out God's wrath on the rivers and springs of water or 2) this was another angel who was in charge of all the waters.
"You" refers to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: the one who is and who was
tn.text: "God who is and who was." See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:01:04|1:4]].

tn.ref: they poured out the blood of the believers and prophets
tn.text: Here "poured out the blood" means killed. AT: "evil people murdered the believers and prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you have given them blood to drink
tn.text: God will make the evil people drink the waters that he turned to blood.
The word "altar" here refers perhaps to someone at the altar. "I heard someone at the altar reply"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "bowl" refers to what is in it. AT: "poured out the wine from his bowl" or "poured out God's wrath from his bowl." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:16:02|16:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: it was given permission to scorch the people
tn.text: John speaks about the sun as if it were a person. This can be stated in active form. AT: "and caused the sun to severely burn the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: They were scorched by the terrible heat
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The extreme heat burned them badly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: they blasphemed the name of God
tn.text: Here the name of God represents God. AT: "they blasphemed God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: who has the power over these plagues
tn.text: This phrase reminds readers of something they already know about God. It helps to explain why the people were blaspheming God. AT: "because he has the power over these plagues" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_distinguish]])
This refers to the power to inflict these plagues on people, and the power to stop the plagues. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The word "bowl" refers to what is in it. AT: "poured out the wine from his bowl" or "poured out God's wrath from his bowl." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:16:02|16:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is where the beast reigns from. It may refer to the capital city of his kingdom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Darkness is spoken of as if it were something like a blanket. AT: "it became dark in all his kingdom" or "all of his kingdom became dark" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to the people in the beast's kingdom.

The word "bowl" refers to what is in it. AT: "poured out the wine from his bowl" or "poured out God's wrath from his bowl." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:16:02|16:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "And its water dried up" or "And caused its water to dry up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
A frog is a small animal that lives near water. Jews considered them unclean animals.

This was a large, fierce reptile, like a lizard. For Jewish people, it was a symbol of evil and chaos. The dragon is also identified in verse 9 as "the devil or Satan." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:12:03|12:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]])
Verse 15 is a break from the main storyline of John's vision. These are words spoken by Jesus. The storyline continues in verse 16.

It can be stated clearly that the Lord Jesus was saying this as in the UDB. The parentheses are used here to show that this is not part of the storyline in the vision. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: I am coming as a thief
tn.text: Jesus will come at a time when people do not expect him, just as a thief comes when not expected. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:03:03|3:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Living the right way is spoken of as keeping one's clothes on. AT: "doing what is right like people keeping their clothes on"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Some versions translate, "keeping his garments with him."
Here the word "they" refers to other people.
"The spirits of the demons brought the kings and their armies together"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the place that people call" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
The seventh angel pours out the seventh bowl of God's wrath.

The word "bowl" refers to what is in it. AT: "poured out the wine from his bowl" or "poured out God's wrath from his bowl." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:16:02|16:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Then a loud voice came out of the temple and from the throne
tn.text: This means someone sitting on the throne or someone standing near the throne spoke loudly. It is unclear who is speaking. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Use your language's way of describing what lightning looks like each time it appears. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:04:04|4:5]].
These are the loud noises that thunder makes. Use your language's way of describing the sound of thunder. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:rev:04:04|4:5]].
This can be stated in active form. AT: "The earthquake split the great city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"Then God remembered" or "Then God thought of" or "Then God started to pay attention to." This does not mean that God remembered something he had forgotten.

tn.ref: he gave that city the cup filled with the wine made from his furious wrath
tn.text: The wine is a symbol of his wrath. Making people drink it is a symbol of punishing them. AT: "he made the people of that city drink the wine that represents his wrath" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_symlanguage]])
This is part of the seventh bowl of God's wrath.

tn.ref: the mountains were no longer found
tn.text: The inability to see any mountains is metonymy expressing the idea that no mountains existed any longer. AT: "there were no longer any mountains" (See:  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"34 kilograms" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])
